posts.content:
Hey, Hi all. I am trying to build a Assassin/Shadowdancer.

I started with Monk/Assassin/SD, but monk didnt have spellcasting, buffing.

Same with Rogue. So I created a thread asking for help with a Bard/Assassin/Shadowdancer.

After I got it up to 9th level(Bard 5/Assassin 2/SD 2, I noticed that its going to be a pain getting the 2 weapon path of feats.

Also lack of Hp, lack of BAB

So I thought of Ranger/Assassin/SD

6+ levels in Ranger would take care of dual wielding path of feats. Rangers would have the class skills, skill points needed. Rangers have good BAB, Rangers have good HP, Rangers wear light armor in a Dex Assassin/SD build, Rangers have buff spells, healing spells, like a Bard. Ranger/Assassins/SD have UMD to use buff, summon, items, scrolls, Rangers have a animal companion, and can cast a summon spell, and can use SD ability to summon a shadow to have 1 animal companion, 1 summoned animal, 1 shadow, 1 Henchman, 1 Ranger/Assassin/SD PC as a nice little party to handle undead or things that cant easily be dealt with by Assassin/SD, and if all that not enough Rangers have Favored Enemy.

So my plan is about 6+ Ranger Levels, high enough to get at least 2nd level Ranger Spells, if not level 3 Ranger Spells, if lev 3 spells does not raise Ranger level too high. 23 to 28 Assassin Levels, 5 SD shadowdancer levels to get HIPS, Evasion, Summon Shadow, Shadow Evade, Defensive Roll.

The feat path will have the dual wield 2 weapon path(Free), dodge, Weapon Finesse, Mobility, Expertise, Whirlwind Attack, Improved, Dev Crit, Knockdown, Blind Fight, Great Dexterity, Armor Skin, Prowess, etc

Thinking of Elf to start with Longsword, Bow, and to help with Knockdown Feat, unless Ranger class gets you martial weapons like Rapier, shortsword, that can be weapon finessed, then be halfling.

So thats the basic concept of build.

What would you guys recommend, suggest?

Especially looking for help from Mick Dagger, Valerfor, Empyre, Steig, etc, but any participation from anybody would also be awesome

Also noticed that altho there is lots of Assassin/SD Builds, there are only 1,2,3 older builds that I have seen by digging that had Ranger/Assassin/SD.

Thanks for any help, participation given.

Mike

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Ok, Asturonethoriusaline
Assassin has the UMD skill, and it is far more versatile than a couple of ranger spells. But ranger has a lot going for it, so building with ranger is one of the better options for assassins (according to my own assassin guide):
"Ranger is the only base class with full warrior BAB progression that has stealth as class skills. Rangers can get 8 ranks in the stealth skills at level 5 and start taking assassin levels at level 6. Rangers are proficient with martial weapons and get the dual wield feats as class feats, with ITWF at level 9, leaving room for all the 10 pre epic assassin levels before level 20. The ranger requirement of dual wielding in light armor fits perfectly for a dexterity-based assassin. Rangers get several spells that help assassins work better. Ultravision helps pierce the darkness spell. The camouflage, one with the land and cat’s grace spells also benefit assassin stealth, AB and AC. The trackless step feat improves stealth when outdoors."

Here is my take on Ranger/ Assassin/ Shadowdancer. It is an elf. You can also build it as a halfling if you switch from swords to daggers.
We still differ on how many SD levels we want, but here is my take on it anyway:

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content:
Asturonethoriusaline wrote: Thanks Mick, that's pretty much 87% to 93% what I had in mind.

We only just barely slightly disagree on about the SD levels, and 1,2,3 feats like Expertise, Dev Crit, improved crit, Whirlwind attack over 1,2,3 feats you chose like Blindfight(ultravision spell and elven darkvision should not make blindfight necessary), maybe not weapon focus(weapon focus only increases attack by a measly +1 and is really not needed for important feats, and I can think of both epic, and normal feats that would be better then epic weapon focus), or maybe 1 less great Dexterity feat.

But the disagreements are only because slight differences in what want such as things like summon shadow, Shadow Evade, Defensive Roll, and that if not for things like that, builds would be almost exactly same.
Ultravision and Darkvision do not cover the same ground as Blind Fight. Please go look at the Wiki for what BF actually does. Whirlwind Attack is a pretty useless Feat on an Assassin Build (better read the Wiki on that one as well). Dev Crit Save is based on Strength and you already have an "I win" button with Death Attack. You can never have too much AB (maybe oversimplifying it, you get an extra 5% hit chance on every attack that's between 5% and 95% hit chance).

You're welcome.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Asturonethoriusaline wrote: Thanks Mick
You're welcome 🙂
I have enjoyed playing this character in single player modules as well as on PWs. I posted the first version of the build in the old Bioware forums, I think it was back in 08.
Asturonethoriusaline wrote: We only just barely slightly disagree on about the SD levels, and 1,2,3 feats like Expertise, Dev Crit, improved crit, Whirlwind attack over 1,2,3 feats you chose like Blindfight(ultravision spell and elven darkvision should not make blindfight necessary), maybe not weapon focus(weapon focus only increases attack by a measly +1 and is really not needed for important feats, and I can think of both epic, and normal feats that would be better then epic weapon focus), or maybe 1 less great Dexterity feat.
Expertise can be a great feat if you need better AC in some situations. Here I mainly use HIPS for crowd control, and I have never missed Expertise.
This is a Dexterity build! You need at least 25 Strength for Devastating Critical and here it is not even an option.
Improved critical is in my opinion a very good feat that increases damage dealt. But here it is completely overshadowed by Death attack damage and I cannot give it priority.  Like Sneak attack damage, Death attack damage is (unfortunately) not muliplied on a critical hit.
Whirlwind attack is something I only take to qualify for Weaponmaster. And even then I only use it to a very limited degree. If I remember correctly, WWA does not trigger SAs or DAs.
Blindfight can not be replaced by Ultravision or Darkvision. They do different things.
If you start to remove WF,  EWF or EP and drop Great dex feats, this killer soon ends up with a pedestrian AB.

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content:
Asturonethoriusaline wrote: Expertise is the only thing I disagree with you guys. Expertise on a weapon finesse dex build is good.

At 3rd level the AB is already at +8 to +10. If I had Expertise now at 3rd Level, I would still have +3(not great, but not bad, but just barely below average)

And that's at 3rd level. At higher levels, expertise will be good.
The -5 to AB affects every attack; at high levels even if you have AB to spare on your first attack, you are 25AB lower on the final one.

OFC whether it's worth having depends very much on your, and your opponents', relative AB vs AC. However, given the number of items that can improve AC and the cap on AB, then it ought to be clear which one you'll be more likely to struggle with at high levels. I'd say it doesn't actually scale well at all and is more likely to be of use at low levels.

posts.author: Asturonethoriusaline
posts.content:
I will agree with you that Expertise is good at the mid levels. I think expertise is worth having on semi lower AC builds, and even sometimes on a semi high AC builds, and worth a feat slot.

After even more thought. Expertise is better, best on at least a semi melee tank, DPS build.

The thing I am forgeting is that while the Ranger/Assassin/SD can be a semi melee build between semi low to semi mid levels, between mid level and semi high levels, and especially at high, highest levels, the build is a hit and run, ambushing, ninja, stealth, almost insta kill build, that only uses AC when cant assassinate, and has to fight hordes, or dragon, etc, in a straight up melee fight.

Having a higher AB and damage output, from a dex build, will almost insta kill, and avoid a melee fight, while a Dex based AC will help when forced into a Melee fight

In that kind of situation Expertise is 50/50 at best on whether help, worth a feat slot.

So I can understand Expertise both not being selected as a feat, and being selected as a feat.

Instead of taking expertise at level 9, after raising 12 int to 13 at lev 8, I may wait until level 15 after raising 12 int to 13 at lev 12, to take expertise, if I take expertise.

My thought is to see if either I can get by without expertise, or if expertise would be helpful. And if I have enough feat slots to take expertise, I can take it. And if not, I can then not take expertise in the build and take something else instead.

So at the very least, I think I should delay taking Expertise until later, if at all.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just a quickie...

I would be astonished if you needed Expertise at all in the OC. I retain a certain fondness for the campaign for 2 reasons: first, because it's the, well, first one; and second, it gets under Max's skin. But it really won't give you much evidence of a good build over a poor one. It matters more with the expansions (SoU and HotU), but really good builds will shine far brighter when taking on other modules or PWs. If you do fancy a tougher OC run, you could do worse than try Hip's challenge in (I think) the Modules section, and play it as it was originally built.

Cheers

posts.author: Asturonethoriusaline
posts.content:
Also. I thought Expertise and its +5 to AC and its -5 to attack was ONLY when you ACTIVATED turned it on.

When you turn it on, yes it -5 to every attack while turned on. But when you turn it off, no +5 to AC, no -5 to AB on attacks.
This way, you can turn it on against lower AC but high AB, high damage opponents, and turn it off against high AC, lower AB, lower damage opponents.

At least thats my understanding of how it works.

If I am wrong, and if expertise is always on no matter what after you take it, then Expertise would be worthless on all builds

Expertise's value is selectively turning it on and off depending on the opponent, situation.

If can't do that, its worthless.

So please let me, others know if expertise is always on after taking it.

posts.author: Thorsson

No, Expertise is a Combat Mode, so can be turned on or off (but can't also be on at the same time as other modes, like Flurry, Power Attack, Dirty Fighting).

I am playing the OC on and off, with my Monk/Fighter/WM build; I never thought it was that bad either (better than SoU IMO). My build has begun to hit its stride now and things are pretty easy, but there are some harder fights to come. My problem is keeping the sidekick alive.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Well let's not even get started on AI henchmen/women in the OC. If they're not dying all over the place they're casting their best spells spells at the solitary wandering goblin rather than the handful of orc shamans waiting just around the corner. Thanks for that.

Believe me, I'm the last person to have a pop at the OC, but I think I've soloed it since my 5th trip (twice with Linu, once with Tomi, once with Sharwyn and once with Daelan).

On a more general note, I think a lot depends on getting familiar with different styles of playing/combat. There was no way I could take on Klauth (the ancient Red Dragon) solo with a Dexer in my earlier days, because I'd only learned how to play one way. Now, meh. That's not me being cocky, it's about me having played a lot more and - more importantly - read and learned from the wealth of knowledge this Guild has to offer. And I'm still more player than builder: but I'm learning.

As to SoU, when you start it from scratch (unlike when I first did - when I assumed it was a follow-on from the OC), it's a much more challenging environment, and good gear is scarce, that's when you start to notice the difference between good, poor, and mediocre builds at lower levels (and then it all gets dip-shit crazy in HotU). And, even with crappy AI, Deekin's worth it for companionship.

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The OC is supposed to be an introductory adventure, a module for you to get into the Neverwinter Nights world and D&D 3rd Edition in general. That dragon is Klauth and he is supposed to be an Epic (CR 25) challenge in Faerun, so he is justified in being tough, besides you have a side-quest that halves his life anyway. I have more problem with the early 3D models of such creatures, the Infinity Engine (Baldur's Gate II etc) did dragons so much better, that seeing this ugly block of polygons totally destroyed it for me. I don't want to mention the crappy A.I at all, seeing a colossal strength 45 creature doing magic missiles instead of using any of its other options was...

Bah, I'll leave a link to the "real" Klauth below so you can witness his power,
